$SPY $TSLA $AAPL $msft $AMZN 

My thoughts on today's selloff .... 

I'm noticing the "experts" are talking a lot about GARP (growth at a reasonable price) lately. Including Cramer himself tonight. Last May, 11 months ago I featured a blog for members (SEE BELOW) on this very topic, and how these overvalued growth stocks would come crashing back to earth. And now everyone wants to play "Monday morning quarterback" after all the damage that will never be undone in most these names. 

460/462 was the level I had targeted for members as the level I was getting  short again, and I have stuck with my belief that we have been experiencing a bear mkt rally. I am still short the mkt, but have been bullish on commodities especially fertilizer names. The trend to me is lower overall, but I caution those who think we see a crash. I don't. 

We are going to be setting up for a short term technical bounce this week. I have my shopping list ready. However, it will only be for a trade. ✌️

"However, we now believe that it is prudent to begin modeling a gentle deceleration in commercial Office 365 seat growth given the combo of the pandemic/work-from-home boost fading and Office 365 penetration into the broader Office installed base now reaching 80%, offset by strong E5 traction and the price increase," Keirstead wrote in a note to clients. 
 
As such, he lowered the estimates for Office 365 revenue growth to 17.4% from 19.1% for Microsoft's (MSFT) fiscal 2023. 
 
Keirstead also lowered estimates for Windows, due to a potential risk of slowing PC growth and in Server Product and LinkedIn due to tough comparisons. 
 
$MSFT   
 
https://seekingalpha.com/news/3822364-microsoft-tumbles-as-ubs-suggests-office-365-could-see-gentle-deceleration

$MSFT   
 
Microsoft shares tumbled on Monday after investment bank UBS said the tech giant could start to see a "gentle deceleration" in Office 365-related growth. 
 
Analyst Karl Keirstead, who rates Microsoft buy with a $360 price target, noted that Office 365 is the company's second-largest product, behind Azure and likely generated $35.1 billion in fiscal 2022 revenue, growing at between 19% and 21% quarter-over-quarter for the last six quarters. 
 
But given that it likely has "high penetration" and benefits from the pandemic and work-from-home boom are starting to fade, Office 365 growth could start to slow. 
 
Keirstead added that Microsoft remains the dominant franchise in the employee productivity software market, with the race between it and Google ($GOOG) ($GOOGL) "effectively over" and is now trying to displace Microsoft Azure by making Google Cloud more competitive.
